participants.participant: Malcolm Gilbert, Head of Investor Relations & Rating Agencies

plist.p: Good morning, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to Zurich's Full Year 2009 Results Presentation. I would first draw your attention to the slide. Slide two, disclaimer and then go on to just give you the agenda for the day, which will be presentation from CEO, Martin Senn followed by presentation by the CFO, Dieter Wemmer and then the Q&A session.
So, without further ado, I'd ask Martin Senn to give his presentation.

Thank you very much, Malcolm. Good morning, ladies and gentlemen, here in the room; good morning, ladies and gentlemen, on the call; and also good morning to colleagues. I do welcome you to 2009 year-end results announcements and this is, as you all know, my first opportunity as Zurich's Chief Executive Officer to address you. And I must tell you I'm pretty excited about the opportunity to do that and I'm very excited about the strong sets of results we're going to discuss today.

At the outset though I must also stress and I would like to acknowledge that this impressive performance is occurred and has occurred under the leadership of Jim Schiro and I want to publicly pay tribute to the eight years of committed service he gave to this great company, and as each of you know, Jim brought a true passion and excitement and the focus into Zurich and has left a true spirit back with all of us here. And it's not only just the seven years of profitability he has brought into that firm but also his confidence and his pride that do mark today the Zurich spirit.

And another legacy Jim left was an institutional commitment to operational excellence and financial discipline. And that is very much rooted in our culture, in fact it is nearly – it nearly became the culture. And I want to – also want to say that Jim throughout these years for all of us became not just a sort of a symbol of a great leader, he became a friend, and more important we all have high respect for him for his leadership or maybe the more important for – more important for his personality, because he also is a great person. And some times we miss him.

So, today as we emerge from one of the most challenging financial markets in generations, our continued success is sticking to those core principle and it is what allows me to present to you such a strong set of 2009 results. Our business operating profit rose 8% to $5.6 billion. Our net income rose 6% to $3.2 billion driven by the sustained operating performances across all our businesses. General Insurance improved its combined ratio, Global Life increased its new business value, and Farmers enhanced its margins even further. And in addition shareholder equity climbed 34% to $29.7 billion. And these results allowed us to drive a 17.2% business operating profit return on equity, once again exceeding our targets.

As importantly they also put Zurich in one of the strongest financial positions it has ever enjoyed and will enable us to react quickly to any opportunities that emerge in a market upturn as well as to withstand any pressures that may arise from any further market corrections. The strength of these numbers rest in the operating performances of our various businesses, so let's look a little closer at their respective results.

In General Insurance profitability continues to be our primary focus. Through the combination of successful reductions, disciplined underwriting, portfolio management, and a below average catastrophe season we were able to achieve a business operating profit of $3.4 billion and this despite lower investment yields, decreased volumes attributable to both the economic environment and the lost business we could not provide because it did not meet our rigorous underwriting standards.

In terms of issues we see, I would highlight the challenges we continue to face in our motor book of business in Italy and in the U.K. And these high loss trends, affecting all players in those markets, have eroded EGI's loss ratio and expected profitability. We do – we have already taken significant reductions as well as other appropriate measures and anticipate market – marked improvements in those businesses in the second half of 2010.

On the positive side results in our commercial business have held up well in a very competitive environment from our Global Corporates division. In Global Life we grew at an impressive pace by maintaining strong profitability and new business margin. In particular, our bank distribution, private banking, and corporate life and pension pillars drove strong organic growth, while we continued to make significant structural change in the business. And this demonstrates the power and the efficiency of our strategy to globalize the business and to industrialize our business model.

At Farmers business operating profits jumped 10% reflecting not just the successful integration of 21st Century but also continued expense management as well as increased profitability from Farmers Re following the increased quota share arrangements.

In our non core businesses, which now include also our banking activities, we improved profitability, but still showed a $290 million loss for the whole year. This result is attributable primarily to increased loan-loss provisions in banking and increases in certain life reserves outweighing positive market movements in Centre and other run off businesses.

Taken together and considered within the context of the global recession, we are very proud of these results as they signal the inherent strengths of our global businesses. Strengths that range from the proven discipline to price risk appropriately, to the ability to integrate new acquisitions, to the capability of finding new ways to grow despite the distractions in the marketplace.

But perhaps the most impressive indicator of how deep these strengths run is our ability from all these markets – is our ability to emerge from all these market turmoil with one of the most solid balance sheets we have ever enjoyed. An economic solvency margin of 136% and Regulatory Solvency I margin of 198% are not accidents. They are the result of a deliberate strategy to protect our balance sheet from the unpredictability of the external environment.

Remember, the promise we sell to our customers is based on the integrity of our balance sheet and we take this promise very, very seriously. But customers are not our only stakeholder, and as a result we must balance the security we provide them with a long-term value we offer to our shareholders.

And this is why we are so pleased to be able to announce that the board will be recommending a CHF 16 per share dividend at our March 30 Annual General Meeting. At a yield of 7.1% and a payout ratio of 66%, this dividend proposal is squarely inline with our shareholder oriented capital management strategy and returns us to the levels of shareholder value we generated prior to the economic crisis. However, we will not undertake a share buyback in 2010, preferring instead to return value to our shareholders through the dividends, and this obviously will enable us to maintain our strong capital position in the future.

Fundamentally, this attractive dividend proposal reflects the board's confidence in the strengths of Zurich's strategy and in the sustainability of its results. That confidence is well placed for today Zurich stands in a very strong position. Our balance sheet is healthy, with both sides of the ledger sheet reflecting a profound appreciation for the risks we take.

Our geographic and market mix is diverse. We are pursuing the right strategies with a proven ability to execute. Our focus on growth is balanced with our commitment to profitability. We enjoy a strong reputation and we enjoy a growing brand presence. And our people are among the most qualified in our sector.

Although this being true, we still do face challenges. We need to anticipate better and react quicker. We need to find ways to grow smarter and drive even greater efficiencies in our operating models. We need to understand more intimately the risks our customers face. And we need to engage our people more fully in what Zurich is and what it can become. And those are the expectations the board has set for my team and for myself. And they are – what I have been focusing on in these early days and I will continue to focus on in the months and in the years to come.

I do bring to these challenges a broad range of international experiences that give me an awareness of what change means in different cultures. And I think I have a deep appreciation for risks with an understanding of the discipline it takes to systematically harness its potential for upside gain.

I do approach issues with a deep-rooted respect for the power of transparency, openness, and candour. And most important as well I believe that values matter. I am very sensitive to the valid interests of our multiple stakeholders. And in all of this I take an approach to leadership that focuses on people and recognizes that it's the decisions and the actions taken by its people that determines a firm's success.

It is fortunate for us and it's fortunate for Zurich that we have a proven winning strategy and that we can ask ourselves difficult questions from a position of strengths. So you should expect continuity in our strategy going forward. We will continue to treat operational and financial discipline as our core principles. I mentioned before this part of the culture as we have developed. And we will continue to pursue profitable growth and operational transformation as our pathways to future success.

Insurance is a long-term business, and we need to make our decisions accordingly, recognizing the need to drive long-term shareholder value by staying sensitive to the increasing expectations of society more generally. The strong results we're announcing today are a reflection of how seriously we take these commitments. And over the next several months, I look forward to sharing with you some of the answers to the tough questions I will be asking.

In closing, let me just highlight the core themes of our 2009 full-year results. By proactively driving expense and market actions we generated solid operating performances across our core businesses. We continue to benefit from a sophisticated approach to risk. Our capital position remains solid and is strong – solid like a rock. Our reputation and brand recognition continue to grow, and our very attractive, highly competitive dividend proposal stands as a testament to our confidence in the future.
Thank you. And now I would like to ask my colleague Dieter Wemmer, Chief Financial Officer for the group, to give us a more detailed review of our financial results. Thank you.

So, thank you Martin and good morning, ladies and gentlemen. Let me start with a little warning. I might speak a few minutes longer than in previous quarters. We have added two slides to the presentation to where we hope it helps your understanding of what the company is doing and will be doing in future.

The fourth quarter continues the earnings recovery based on actually our sustained operating performance. So, I am starting off on page 10 with warnings with the financial numbers. If we look on slide 10 and go to the upper chart first, the core operating business performed consistently through 2009, particularly bearing in mind the one-off benefit in the third quarter from debt unlocking in the U.S Life business and the profit from the buyback of the hybrid debt. Together, this gave the third quarter a benefit of about $300 million.

In the fourth quarter, the core operating profit was 1.4 billion and non-core recovered well to $143 million profit. Our aim with the non-core businesses has been to take action to bring future results back into a medium-term positive run rate and this has been achieved in the fourth quarter.

Looking at the graph at the bottom of the slide, you can see the after-tax operating profit or BOP after-tax per quarters as the bars track against the net income after tax. The first quarter 2008 on the left shows the pattern we have seen in many quarters previously. Net income after tax slightly higher than business operating profit after tax because of small but consistent net realized gains. The dip into the end of 2008 and into 2009 shows that the financial crisis had its effect on net income after tax. But you can see the continuing recovery in the quarterly numbers. In addition, you can see that the historic pattern is reemerging of net income after tax very near or in future slightly above the operating profit after tax as the effect of the capital market crisis recedes.

Let's now move to General Insurance. General Insurance has in 2009 delivered strong operating performance based on a significantly improved underwriting result. This is a direct result of our focus on pricing discipline and expense management. We set out to increase rates to counter falling investment yields using a differentiated approach and to control expenses. We have achieved it.

Looking at the top line development, we have seen a reduction in gross within premium by 4% year-over-year in local currency. Net written premium is also down by 4%. We have been buying less reinsurance. In 2010 we will employ some more of our surplus capital at our required hurdle rates by increasing our participation and net retentions on our current book of business. The main factors behind the premium decrease continue to include firstly our maintained underwriting discipline where we are still not prepared to write business below our profitability hurdles as well as our differentiated approach to rate changes.

Secondly, increased rates, 3.3% year-over-year while at the same time keeping overall retention rates at comparably high levels. Thirdly, we clearly have to recognize the impact from the reduced economic activity in many markets and as a result the volumes of our insured exposures have come down in particular in North America.

Looking at the individual business divisions, although Global Corporate shrank the top line by 1% in local currency, we achieved rate increases across the book as well as targeted growth in selected markets like European financial lines as well as our expansion into Asia Pacific and Middle East.

North America Commercial on the other hand continues to be heavily affected by reduced demand for insurance capacity in some of its key business segments. In particular, construction and automotive dealers accounted for about half of the reduction. We have, however, largely maintained our customer base and have achieved growth in certain areas including our global and national strategic broker channels. Europe General Insurance reduced premium slightly in local currency even though we have successfully increased rates in most markets. This was driven by our personal lines business due to a very competitive environment as well as underwriting actions taken to counter issues in our motor portfolio mainly in the U.K. and Italy. At the same time, our Commercial lines business managed to maintain volumes.

International markets achieved a local currency growth of 3% during the year with Latin America growing by 17% based on both organic growth and through the acquisition of Minas Brasil end of 2008. In Asia Pacific the underlying growth rate was 7%, but partially offset by the transfer of business to Global Corporate. In all, this resulted in a 1% increase in operating profit in local currency with the improved underwriting result already having absorbed, lower premium volumes compensating the drop in investment results.

Another achievement is that our operating margins both gross and net have increased year-over-year in a difficult environment. I will now go through the key profit drivers in detail starting with the rate change monitor. As mentioned, General Insurance rates are up by 3.3%, a marginal improvement compared to the nine months. This is a great achievement in a market where many players focus solely on share and shows that our margin protection efforts through differentiated rate increases are successful. If you dive into the details, we see that the distribution of these rate increases across the different portfolios have changed in the fourth quarter.

Rate increases on our Corporate and Commercial lines in North America have moderated in the last quarter. This should not come as a surprise as our dedicated rate initiatives were started in the last quarter 2008 and in North America these increases start to compound as I will explain in a minute.

This, however, more than offset by European General Insurance where the rate increases have accelerated compared to the nine months. At the same time, Global Corporate in Europe and international markets achieved similar rate increases to those at the nine months. The reason for the higher level of rate increases in Europe is twofold. Firstly, we are gaining traction in our push for higher rates in our Commercial segment. Secondly, we have the market-wide motor portfolio deterioration seen in certain countries. The push for additional rate in personal lines forms the part of the mitigating actions taking to counter these hat-tricks. In Italy, we are in addition canceling distribution contracts and restricting premium discounts for agents failing to meet our required return expectations. In the U.K., we also have a dedicated claims management strategy in place to offsets the negative effects from claims farming activities in the market. Also, we recently announced that we will increase personal lines motor rate in the U.K. by up to additional 20% starting in March.

Let's now see at the rate changes from another angle. We showed this slide at our nine months presentation. To repeat, the graph shows a simplified view of policies renewing in each quarter over a two-year period, that is, policies that renewed in Q1 2008 average experienced a rate reduction of 2.4% and then in the following year 2009 a 2.1 rate increase. By taking a two-year perspective, this special block of policies experienced an effective rate decrease of 0.4%.

Obviously, this simplification does not account for lapses and new business in each period but provides an overview of our response to cost drivers like inflation, interest rates and changes in frequency. We have observed that new business pricing is in an area where the overall market appears less disciplined. Once again, I want to highlight that we apply the same pricing discipline and methodology based on technical price for both new and renewed business. As you remember, the compounded rate increases have developed favorably over the first three quarters, although we saw the highest rate change in the second quarter of 2009. This trend has continued in the fourth quarter which means that the compounded rate increases is two percentage points higher quarter-on-quarter at 4.9%. This means that our market-leading push in defense of margins continues unabated.

Rate increases are still needed to cover claims trends as well as lower yields. This, however, only provides a written view, but does not tell us how these rate changes are earned through the bottom line. So, let's have a closer look and that is slide number 14.

If you look at the written rate changes over 2008 and '09, you can see that the negative rates written in 2008 vastly earned through in 2009. This has initially offset the positive impact from rate increases achieved in the fourth quarter 2008 and after. The red line in the graph represents an estimate of how cumulative written rate earned in over time. As you can see, the 2009 year-to-date earned impact for the full year makes up just a bit more than 1% which leaves the majority of the written rate change still unearned. This in turn means that a major part of the 2009 rate actions will be earned in 2010.
In addition, we have good news on the underlying performance of our General Insurance book of business where we can report an improvement in the underlying loss ratio of 0.4 percentage points.

Looking at this in more detail, we can see a number of very interesting points. Firstly, our North American business, North America Commercial and Global Corporate in North America drove through a 1.5 percentage point improvement in the underlying loss ratio and this in a very competitive marketplace.

Secondly, if you look at our Corporate and Commercial business in Europe, we see an even better situation with the underlying loss ratio improving 2.5 percentage points. And thirdly, European Personal lines were adversely affected by the performance of our motor books in the U.K., Italy and Russia. Without this we would have delivered a stable underlying loss ratio in Europe Personal lines; all in a very competitive marketplace.

So why have we seen these improvements even though rates have not fully earned through. The answer lies in our differentiated approach to rate increases which means that we apply higher rate increases for the less profitable segments of each individual portfolio. This resulted in a much lower retention in these segments and through the higher lapse rates the average profitability of the portfolio improved.
So, in summary, we have 2009 rate increases still to earn through in 2010 and we have a better quality and price book of business. Both factors support our expectation of sustainability of earnings.

So, now, let's move to the loss ratio in more detail. Overall the reported loss ratio improved 1.6 points to 70.9% year-on-year, which can be fully explained by the benign catastrophe experience this year. Large losses increased somewhat during the year, but still within a reasonable range. On the other hand, you can see that we have not reported any major catastrophes in 2009. Looking at the development of prior year reserves I remind you of the charges we took for asbestos in the second and third quarter of a total net $200 million. The total gain from prior year development was just over 1 billion which means the fourth quarter added just $500 million. In all, this resulted in the improved underlying loss ratio which I explained and discussed already before.

Now, let's move to the expense ratio development on slide 16. The 0.4 percentage point increase in expense ratio is not driven by the volume reductions. The increase is instead driven by higher levels of commission based on changes in business mix as well as a modified approach to broker remuneration. As a result, the commission ratio increased by 0.3 percentage points year-over-year. At the same time, our disciplined expense management kept our other technical expenses in line with declining volumes. The reasons behind the largely flat ratio for other technical expenses are the achievement of our lead-to-market expense saving program where General Insurance contributed about $250 million. Included in the underwriting expenses are the ongoing investment we make in profitable growth and operational transformation. Those examples include our Middle East expansion and our integrated product unit in North America.

Now, let's have a closer look at the loss reserve levels. In 2009, we saw our results grow by 2% net of currency effect. The reason for this increase is additional business taken on to the Group's book through the increased quota share reinsurance agreement with the Farmers Exchanges. On a like-for-like basis, the reserve levels remain flat underlying that our reserving conservatism remains unchanged. Looking at claims payments excluding the effect from the growth of the Farmers Re quota share, the increases are due to higher loss loads on European motor and reserve.

With this, let's now look at the Life business. The strategy which Global Life has been following is evident in the excellent results of 2009. These results are remarkable both in absolute terms and relative to the performance of the sector. All six pillars are now fully operational and contributing to our growth targets. In conjunction with this we have been developing global propositions and our operational hub strategy. Global Life reported 28% growth in local currency in gross written premium, policy fees and deposits.

This growth along with the focus on in-force management drove the policyholder net inflow to a positive $5.4 billion for the year. The increase in new business volume of 19% in local currency reflects strong growth in Spain benefiting not only from the effect of the business acquired last year but also from strong organic growth of 76%. We also achieved 44% local currency growth in Latin America from individual and corporate protection and savings products. In the U.K., we achieved local currency premium growth of 6% with more long-term savings and bank distribution deals. In Ireland, we continue to gain market share reaching 15% in a market that has declined by over 25%. This growth balanced reductions in emerging markets in Asia and slightly lower sales in the U.S.

The new business margin at 21.3% reflects both, our ability to hold expenses flat as we invest in our strategy and industrialize our operating model as well as the effects of a shift in product mix to protection and long-term savings in response to changing market conditions. The growth and sustained margin resulted in a new business value of 782 million, up 9% in local currency. This strong value was driven by volume growth in Spain and Latin America, as already mentioned before, but also by our new operating unit in Luxembourg and from improved margins in the U.K. Lower interest rates benefited the U.S. and Australia, but adversely affected Switzerland and Germany.

The embedded value operating earnings which are now fully compliant with the CFO Forum's MCEV principles were 1.9 billion representing an operating EV return of 14.9% for the year. The operating earnings benefited from the strong new business performance as well as impact of the change to full MCEV principles. Focused management of expenses and the in-force business led to a positive operating variance overall.

I will discuss the business operating profit of the segment in a minute when taking you through our profit by source analysis. But now, let's spend a few moments on the details on the Global Life new business by distribution channel. Bank Distribution was the main growth driver growing 55%, primarily in Spain where the new business acquired continued to perform well. In addition, the U.K. business grew from the sale of newly introduced investment product through our banking partners.

The Private Banking Client Solution achieved sales of $186 million from a standing start through the new private banking hub in Luxembourg. Sales were generated in the U.K. and Italy contributing almost $2 billion of new assets under management. The Corporate Life & Pension pillar grew 60% in local currency driven by strong sales of protection business to international groups leveraging relationships of our Global Corporate business and from local protection sold in Ireland, Latin America and U.K. The IFA/Broker pillar increased by 11% in local currency despite difficult market conditions. We had good growth in Italy and in the U.K., the later as a result of successful pension sales. These were partially offset by weaker unit-linked growth elsewhere, especially in Germany.

For both, our Asian and International/Expat pillar, most operations continue to achieve growth. However, as already mentioned last quarter, our Hong Kong business, both domestic and International/Expat was significantly affected by a fall in consumer appetite in unit-linked products, although we saw a small improving trend in the fourth quarter.

Now, turning to slide number 20 and to profit by source analysis. As communicated at the Global Life Investor Day last May, we have been developing the profit by source analysis internally to better assess and drive our Life business operating profit. I would like to take you through the operating result with a focus on the three key insurance margins of expense, risk and investment. The Global Life business operating profit of 1.5 billion decreased by 1% in dollar terms but increased 5% in local currencies.

Overall, the underlying run rate of the business has remained strong with the new business trend reduced despite the strong new business growth. The reported business operating profit has benefited from a higher level of one-off compared to the prior year, which amounted to a number of about $260 million, unchanged from the level at nine months. The expense margin has increased 49% in local currency benefiting from lower new business trend, underlying expenses being held flat year-over-year, as well as a one-off benefit from the debt unlocking as reported before.

This was offset by reduced fund-based fees due to the lower average stock market level and reduced non-fund-based fees, primarily due to lower premium levels in Germany and Switzerland compared to the year before.

Thanks to strong policyholder inflows and market recovery assets under management are higher at the end of 2009. Therefore, we are off to a promising start in 2010 certainly as far as fund-based fees are concerned. The risk margin has improved 9% in local currency driven by favorable experience, less external reinsurance costs and the growth in risk volumes as a result of strong protection sales which I have already mentioned.

The investment margin has improved 10% in local currency as a result of the slightly lower return on shareholder assets more than compensated by an increased investment margin over guarantees and other policyholder participation. Other profits have decreased mainly due to the inclusion of one-off benefit from reinsurance of non-core annuities in the year before. The interest, depreciation, amortization and non-controlling interests have increased primarily due to a full-year impact of the acquisitions that occurred in the third quarter 2008. You can find more details in the appendix regarding the profit by source results.

Now, let's move to our third business segment, Farmers. Again, Farmers has produced a high quality set of results which combine growth, profitability and expense control. Let's start with the Management company. The margin on gross earned premium is up over prior year to an excellent 7.2% as we continue to manage our expenses through various initiatives. Operating profit increased by 10% or $124 million driven by these expense initiatives as well as a higher top line at the Exchanges driven by the acquired 21st Century business. In the first six months since acquisition, 21st Century added over 210 million to management fees, over 80 million to operating profit at the Management company level as well as 1.1 billion of premium at the Exchange level.

The other effect of the deal is that the increased quota share we have taken which gave a BOP benefit of additional 43 million at Farmers Re in the second half of '09. I will update you on the integration focus in a minute and you can find more financial information on 21st Century in the appendix of this presentation.

Moving on to Farmers Re, Farmers Re gross within premium are up by $3.2 billion over prior year as a result of increased quota share with the Exchanges in two steps; from 5 to 25% in late 2008 and in turn to 37.5%, as well as benefiting from growth in the Exchanges' top line. In light of the strong solvency position at the Exchanges, this quota share has been reduced to 35% with the effect of end of December 2009. As a result of the growth in premium and investment income, operating profit increased to $228 million at the Farmers Re level.

Now, let's have a short look at the Exchanges. The Exchanges, which we manage but do not own, have maintained the strong growth track record which started back in 2006. Gross written premium increased 5.4% largely as a result of the acquisition of 21st Century in the second half. Excluding the acquisition and the small business transfer from North America Commercial, the Exchanges top line has reduced by 2.1% overall in a contracting market driven by the auto book as a result of the difficult economic environment in the U.S. and competitive pressure.

The adjusted combined ratio is 91.3%, 7.1 percentage points better than a year ago, 4.3 are due to lower catastrophe experience and the balance is driven by price increases earnings through as well as improving loss trends mainly in the auto book. As I have already alluded to, net surplus increased by $575 million and the surplus ratio rose to 43%, putting the Exchanges in a very comfortable surplus position.

Now, let me update you on the acquisition of 21st Century more specifically. Our 21st Century acquisition has been included in these results for six months. As you can see, 21st Century wrote over $2.4 billion of premium for the full year 2009. An ever increasing proportion is from the direction channel as agency auto is being folded in the Exchanges Foremost plant. As a result of negative residual effect of legacy brand issues and a challenging U.S. economy, direct premiums have experienced a downward trend, however, at a decreasing rate. It is very encouraging to see that monthly renewal retention rates are bouncing back to levels close to 82%. Still, higher retentions are not sufficient to offset lower new business. However, we are also seeing positive signs here. The new business application in November and December '09 and also January 2010 are higher than in the same months the year before. 21st Century's combined ratio has seen some minor uptick in Q4 driven by seasonal and one-off effects.

We continue to believe that the acquisition remains on track to achieve earnings per share accretion in year one because of the integration synergies we have achieved. Annual run rate savings in the Management company amounts to $45 million while savings in the Exchanges will contribute to their profitability and surplus as well as to the underwriting results of the quota share. We are running a state of the art integration process. 55 out of 65 AIG transition services have been closed off on or ahead of schedule. The remaining 10 will be closed off by the end of the first quarter 2010. Further consolidation into Farmers' operations continues as scheduled in 2010 and will include areas such as data center, IT application and claims operations. In summary, the integration is really well on track.

Let's now look at the other operating and non-core businesses to complete the run through of the businesses. Other operating businesses include net head office expenses, external debt costs and some sample foreign currency gains and losses, the result – and the results for alternative investments. As we reported at the third quarter, there was a gain of $200 million from buying back subordinated debt over the summer. The non-core businesses segment had a loss for the year of 290 million. It made a profit of 143 million in the fourth quarter when we have seen benefits of the further recovery in the financial markets in the quarter and from increase in commutation gains in a number of our run-off businesses.

All parts of non-core businesses made a profit in the quarter with the exception of the banking business where we further increased loan provisions in Ireland and in the U.K. by 50 million overall in response to new information on a few specific loans. While the non-core business segment is relatively sensitive to extreme capital market volatility in the absent of large market correction, we believe these businesses are back in a stable position and expect them to revert to running off at a small profit over time. We have taken additional hedging actions to protect the U.S. Life business in run-off against falling markets. We are investigating changing the hedge structure to potentially a full dynamic hedge to reduce future hedging costs. This could potentially warrant a different accounting treatment of that block of business with the usual restatement consequences in accordance with IFRS 9.

Looking now at the performance of our Group investments on page – slide 24 for the audience on the phone. Net investment income decreased by 14% in dollar terms and 9% in local currency driven by lower dividends on equities and reinvestments at lower interest rates. Net capital losses through P&L were $1.4 billion for the full year and 0.2 billion in the fourth quarter. Positive mark-to-market adjustments in the last quarter were offset by some impairment on bonds, equities and mortgage loans, as I mentioned, as well as the mark-to-market losses on risk reduction hedges of about 50 million. You can find as usually the details in the appendix.

Net investment returns through P&L was a positive 3.2% for the 2009, slightly up compared to 2008. Changes in unrealized losses on investments included in equity were a positive 5.7 billion for the full year and a negative 0.2 billion in the fourth quarter. Although equities and asset-backed bonds have posted gains in the last quarter, government bonds lost about 0.7 billion as yields increased in the last weeks of the year. As a result, total investment return for the full year 2009 amounted to a strong 6.3% compared to 1% in 2008. Throughout 2009 the key principles of Zurich's disciplined investment approach remain unchanged and as always, you can find further details around our investment portfolio in the further slides. Our equity exposure is well controlled and amounts now to 2.9% at the end of December taking into account our hedging program which protects about 16% of the equity exposure.

Now, let's look at our shareholders' equity development. Shareholders' equity at $29.7 billion, a new historic high, is $7.6 billion up on the 2008 year-end number. Most of the increase, as you can see on the slide, increase arose in the second and third quarter. The increase of 1.2 billion in the fourth quarter was largely driven by the net income of 1.1 billion while further or other movements were fairly small.

Now, let's summarize our capital position on slide 26. Solvency ratio grew due to retained earnings during the fourth quarter as asset and liability values remained relatively stable. Our solvency run ratio is very healthy at 198% after accruing for the dividend which reduces the ratio by 17%. Solvency II remains a hot topic for the industry. Quite clearly, there is much uncertainty on the details and we are taking our full part in the industry discussion. However, as a Group we are subject to the Swiss Solvency Test. This is well into its pilot phase and we are very comfortable with our estimated SST ratio.

I spoke last quarter about the expected developments on transferring more business to our EU-based General Insurance carrier. We have achieved the transfer of the business in Spain, Italy and Portugal through our timetable for January 1, 2010. The main block of business is still to be transferred as our German business which we expect to move across later this year. This will result in a single EU company with a broad branch structure and with a gross written premium of about $15 billion.

Moving now to our internal economic solvency model at the bottom of the chart. This has remained stable through the quarter and after accruing for the dividend and the 2010 expected growth requirements, is at 136%.
